text: today on x cast increasing tensions in
Tahrir Square as protesters show no sign
of leaving journalists and human rights
workers in Egypt are being singled out
today alone we've tracked well over 50
50 cases of violations against
journalists and a look at the Islamist
group that may become key to US
relations with Egypt this is steven
farrell the new york times in Tahrir
Square i've been here since about six
o'clock in the morning and the mood here
is very very defiant lots of new people
are coming in we've spoken to many
people around the square and they've
saying a sickened by what they saw
yesterday they're sickened by the facts
on the protesters in the square
yesterday and they've decided to come
and reinforce them Tahrir Square is
essentially two squares at the moment in
the center here it's almost a carnival a
party atmosphere this free food is free
drink they're adopters providing
medicine it feels very safe right here
right now which is mid afternoon just
300 meters 300 yards away from me it's a
completely different mood this is the
other side of town square in both senses
behind me there's just been a running
battle between pro-government forces and
anti-government forces it was very
confusing gratuite airy elevated highway
the square north of takbir
pro-government forces were on part of
one anti-government forces on par to
another they were surging backwards and
forwards backwards of all words it was
impossible to know who was who between
the Egyptian army tanks were moving
circling shots were being fired you
couldn't tell who from who to nobody
knows it was going to be more violence
over the coming hours and days but it's
certainly another day of high tension in
and around Tahrir Square this is steven
far above the New York Times I'm brian
Stelter in doha qatar visiting the
headquarters of al-jazeera one of the
media outlets that's come under severe
scrutiny by the Egyptian government in
recent days as the government tries to
stop access to the protests that
continue in the streets of Cairo on
Thursday to hear there was a systematic
attempt to remove the witnesses to the
battles that are ongoing in the streets
as journalists and other observers like
human rights workers were repeatedly
targeted some journalists were arrested
others were detained and others were
beaten observers say the violence
against journalists increased markedly
on Thursday today alone we've tracked
well over 50 50 cases of violations
against journalists over the days it has
intensified and now it's an all-out
assault on really information itself one
al Jazeera reporter Dan Nolan wrote on
Twitter on Thursday that thanks to a
state media campaign on Egyptian
television trying to demonize out
Jazeera now pro-mubarak protesters were
hunting al Jazeera staff and we've seen
that from other journalists as well like
CNN's Anderson Cooper on Wednesday night
we know for a fact from from from
previous experiences whenever whenever
government is so intent on eliminating
witnesses that this is usually a
precursor to some very violent act the
frequencies brow Jazeera the satellite
signals have been changed repeatedly
it's been hard to keep up at times but
in a show of solidarity a few days ago
other state channels in the region
started simulcasting al Jazeera's
broadcast there is still no clear
opposition leader in Egypt but as Scott
Shane reports one of the few near
certainties of a post mobile
Egypt will include a more powerful
Muslim Brotherhood the role of Muslim
Brotherhood has actually been very minor
until today at least they they were not
among the organizers of the protests and
they have deliberately kept a low
profile today however they did issue a
statement calling for mubarak to step
down and calling for a multi-party
coalition to take power the Muslim
Brotherhood was found in 1928 and today
it's the biggest Islamist movement in
the Muslim world has branches in many
countries but it was really born in
Egypt where it is the largest opposition
force against Mubarak and has been from
for many years officially it's banned
there but in a post mubarak Egypt it is
almost certain to take on an important
political role the real question is
whether it would be satisfied with being
one of a number of parties and sharing
power or whether it would seek to
monopolize power and install a regime
guided by Islamic law Sharia American
officials through several
administrations have not fully trusted
the Brotherhood's renunciation of
violence and perhaps for most American
administrations have not appreciated the
Brotherhood's open hostility to Israel
Egypt had signed a peace treaty with
Israel and the Obama administration now
realizes it probably has to deal with
the Brotherhood but it's very concerned
about the future of that peace treaty
and the future of relations between
Egypt and Israel
join us again tomorrow four times cast
